title: 108_hr1874
content: The Act titled "David Jayne Homebound Reform Act of 2003" clarifies the definition of homebound through a demonstration project. The "David Jayne Homebound Reform Act of 2003" includes a demonstration project where Medicare beneficiaries with chronic conditions can be deemed homebound for receiving home health services, regardless of the purpose, frequency, or duration of absences from home, if certified by a physician with a permanent and severe condition. The "David Jayne Homebound Reform Act of 2003" allows Medicare beneficiaries with chronic conditions to be considered homebound for receiving home health services if certified by a physician with a permanent and severe condition that requires assistance for daily living activities, home health services, and technological assistance to leave the home. The "David Jayne Homebound Reform Act of 2003" allows Medicare beneficiaries with chronic conditions to be considered homebound for receiving home health services if certified by a physician with a permanent and severe condition that requires assistance for daily living activities, home health services, and technological assistance to leave the home. The Act also mandates the collection of data on the provision of home health services to Medicare beneficiaries for quality of care, patient outcomes, and additional costs to the Medicare program. Additionally, reports to Congress are required within one year of the implementation of the demonstration project under this section. The "David Jayne Homebound Reform Act of 2003" mandates data collection on home health services for Medicare beneficiaries, focusing on quality of care, patient outcomes, and costs to the Medicare program. The Secretary must submit reports to Congress within one year of the project's implementation. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress within one year of implementing the "David Jayne Homebound Reform Act of 2003" project, using data collected under subsection (c). Waiver authority allows the Secretary to waive compliance with certain requirements of the Social Security Act for demonstration projects, without affecting available penalties or remedies under title XI or XVIII. The Secretary can waive compliance with Social Security Act requirements for demonstration projects without affecting penalties or remedies under title XI or XVIII. No waiver applies to civil or criminal penalties for false certifications under the Medicare program. Authorization of appropriations is available from the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Supplementary Insurance Trust Fund. Authorization of appropriations is available from the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Supplementary Insurance Trust Fund for the costs of carrying out the demonstration project under this section. Definitions include "medicare beneficiary" and "home health services." The term "medicare beneficiary" refers to an individual entitled to benefits under part A or enrolled under part B. "Home health services" are defined as in section 1861(m) of the Social Security Act. "Activities of daily living" include eating, toileting, transferring, bathing, and dressing. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. Clarification of the definition of homebound for determining eligibility for home health services under the Medicare program. The Social Security Act is amended to include provisions for individuals with permanent and severe conditions requiring assistance with daily living activities and home health services to achieve a functional condition allowing them to leave home. Individuals with at least 3 out of 5 activities of daily living, requiring home health services to achieve a functional condition enabling them to leave home, may not be disqualified from being considered 'confined to his home' based on absences. Activities of daily living include eating, toileting, transferring, bathing, and dressing. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will submit a report to Congress by December 1, 2006, analyzing the effects of a demonstration project established under section 2. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will submit a report to Congress by December 1, 2006, analyzing the effects of a demonstration project on home health services under the Medicare program. The project will be discontinued on January 1, 2007, unless data collected shows a positive impact on the clarification of the definition of homebound. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress by December 1, 2006, analyzing the effects of a demonstration project on home health services under Medicare. The project will end on January 1, 2007, unless data shows a positive impact on the definition of homebound. If adverse effects or unreasonable cost increases are found, they will be included in the report. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress analyzing the effects of a demonstration project on home health services under Medicare. If the report includes findings of increased expenditures directly attributable to a clarification, specific data on the increase in expenditures will be provided. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress analyzing the effects of a demonstration project on home health services under Medicare, including specific recommendations to exempt permanently and severely disabled homebound beneficiaries from restrictions on the length, frequency, and purpose of their absences from home to qualify for services without incurring additional costs to the program. Technical amendments to sections 1814(a) and 1835(a) will be made. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress analyzing the effects of a demonstration project on home health services under Medicare, with recommendations to exempt permanently and severely disabled homebound beneficiaries from restrictions on absences from home to qualify for services without incurring additional costs. Technical amendments to sections 1814(a) and 1835(a) will be made. Section 1814(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to move a sentence to the end of the section.
